intro: Alsine fasciculata var. pubescens, commonly known as the hairy alsine, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Amaranthaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and hairy foliage. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid regions. It has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, greenish-white flowers that bloom in late spring. The hairy texture of its stems and leaves is a distinguishing feature of this variety.
